{{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Russian philosophy]] |era = [[20th-century philosophy]] |name = Nikolai Berdyaev |image =Berdiayev001.jpg |birth_name=Nikolai Alexandrovich Berdyaev |birth_date = March 18, 1874 |birth_place = [[Kiev]], [[Kiev Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1948|3|24|1874|3|18}} |death_place = [[Clamart]], [[France]] |school_tradition = [[Christian existentialism]], [[personalism]] |main_interests = [[Creativity]], [[eschatology]], [[Freedom (philosophy)|freedom]] |influences = [[Jacob Böhme|Böhme]], [[Saint Seraphim of Sarov|Seraphim of Sarov]], [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]], [[Franz Xaver von Baader|Baader]], [[Aleksey Khomyakov|Khomyakov]], [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky|Dostoyevsky]], [[Konstantin Leontiev|Leontiev]], [[Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)|Solovyov]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]], [[Semyon Frank]], [[Hegel]], [[Sergey Bulgakov]] |influenced = [[Jacques Ellul|Ellul]], [[Aldous Huxley|Huxley]], [[Richard Kroner|Kroner]], [[Gabriel Marcel|Marcel]], [[Davor Džalto|Džalto]], [[Peter Maurin|Maurin]], [[Alan Watts|Watts]], [[Semyon Frank]], [[Sergey Bulgakov]], [[Ivan Devčić]] |notable_ideas = Core motifs: freedom, the person, spirit, creativity }} [[File:Tombe Berdiaev2.JPG|thumb|Berdyaev's grave, Clamart (France).]] '''Nikolai Alexandrovich Berdyaev''' ({{IPAc-en|b|ər|ˈ|d|j|ɑː|j|ɛ|f|,_|-|j|ɛ|v}};[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/berdyaev "Berdyaev"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''. {{lang-ru|Никола́й Алекса́ндрович Бердя́ев}}; {{OldStyleDate|March 18|1874|March 6}} – March 24, 1948) was a Russian political and also Christian religious [[philosophy|philosopher]] who emphasized the [[Existentialism|existential]] spiritual significance of [[Personalism|human freedom]] and the human person. Alternate historical spellings of his name in English include "Berdiaev" and "Berdiaeff", and of his given name as "Nicolas" and "Nicholas". ==Biography== {{More footnotes|section|date=October 2017}} Nikolai Berdyaev was born at [[Obukhiv]],Technically at the time "Obykhov" or "Obuchovo" {{cite book | last =Lowrie | title =Rebellious Prophet | page =14}}. https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Обухов_(город)] indicates "В Обухове родились: Николай Бердяев — русский религиозный и политический философ. [[Kiev Governorate]] in 1874, in an [[aristocracy|aristocratic]] [[military]] family.{{cite book | last = Nicolaus | first = Georg | authorlink = | title = C.G. Jung and Nikolai Berdyaev : individuation and the person : a critical comparison | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=i07qx0svAf0C&printsec=frontcover&hl=ru#v=onepage&q&f=false | archiveurl = | archivedate = | accessdate = | type = | edition = | series = | date = | origyear = | year = 2011 | month = | publisher = [[Routledge]] | location = | isbn = 9780415493154 | oclc = | doi = | bibcode = | id = | page = | pages = | nopp = | at = | chapter = Chapter 2 "Berdyaev’s life" | chapterurl = http://media.routledgeweb.com/pp/common/sample-chapters/9780415493161.pdf | quote = | laysummary = | laydate = | postscript = | lastauthoramp = }} His father, Alexander Mikhailovich Berdyaev, came from a long line of Kiev and [[Kharkov]] nobility. Almost all of Alexander Mikhailovich's ancestors served as high-ranking military officers, but he resigned from the army quite early and became active in the social life of the Kiev aristocracy. Nikolai's mother, Alina Sergeevna Berdyaeva, was half-French and came from the top levels of both French and Russian nobility. He also had [[Polish people|Polish]] as well as [[Tatar people|Tatar]] origins.George M. Young, ''The Russian Cosmists: The Esoteric Futurism of Nikolai Fedorov and His Followers'', Oxford University Press (2012), p. 134Stefan Berger & Alexei Miller, ''Nationalizing Empires'', Central European University Press (2015), p. 312 Greatly influenced by [[Voltaire]], his father was an educated man that considered himself a [[freethought|freethinker]] and expressed great skepticism towards religion. Nikolai's mother, [[Eastern Orthodox]] by birth, was in her views on religion more [[Catholicism|Catholic]] than Orthodox. He spent a solitary childhood at home, where his father's library allowed him to read widely. He read [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegel]], [[Arthur Schopenhauer|Schopenhauer]], and [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] when he was only 14 and excelled at languages. Berdyaev decided on an intellectual career and entered the [[Kiev University]] in 1894. It was a time of revolutionary fervor among the students and the [[intelligentsia]]. He became a [[Marxism|Marxist]] and he was arrested in a student demonstration and expelled from the university. His involvement in illegal activities led in 1897 to three years of internal [[exile]], [[Vologda]],{{rp|28}} in northern Russia, a mild sentence compared to that faced by many other revolutionaries. In 1904, he married [[Lydia Berdyaev|Lydia Yudifovna Trusheff]]. The couple moved to [[Saint Petersburg]], the Russian capital, and the centre of intellectual and revolutionary activity. He participated fully in intellectual and spiritual debate, eventually departing from radical Marxism to focus his attention on philosophy and Christian spirituality. A fiery 1913 article, entitled "Quenchers of the Spirit", criticising the [[Imiaslavie#Storming the monastery|rough purging]] of [[Imiaslavie]] Russian monks on [[Mount Athos]] by the [[Holy Synod]] of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] using tsarist troops, caused him to be charged with the crime of [[blasphemy]], the punishment for which was exile to [[Siberia]] for life. The [[World War I|World War]] and the [[Bolshevik Revolution]] prevented the matter coming to trial.''Self-Knowledge: An Essay in Autobiography'', by Nicolas Berdyaev (Author), Katharine Lampert (Translator), Boris Jakim (Foreword) {{ISBN|1597312584}} After the [[October Revolution]] of 1917, as the [[Bolshevik]] régime began consolidating its power with a growing suppression of non-Lenin Marxist Intelligentsia, Berdyaev remained steadfast in his criticism of its [[totalitarianism]] and the domination of the state over the freedom of the individual. Nonetheless, he was permitted, for the time being, to continue to lecture and write. His disaffection culminated, in 1919, with the foundation of his own private academy, the ''"Free Academy of Spiritual Culture"''. It was primarily a forum for him to lecture on the hot topics of the day and to present them from a Christian point of view. He also presented his opinions in public lectures, and every Tuesday, the academy hosted a meeting at his home because [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|official Soviet anti-religious activity was intense]] at the time and the official policy of the Bolshevik government, with its [[Soviet anti-religious legislation]], strongly promoted [[State atheism]]. In 1920, Berdiaev became professor of philosophy at the [[University of Moscow]]. In the same year, he was accused of participating in a conspiracy against the government; he was arrested and jailed. The feared head of the [[Cheka]], [[Felix Dzerzhinsky]], came in person to interrogate him,{{cite book | last = Solzhenitsyn | first = Aleksandr | authorlink = Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn | title = The Gulag Archipelago, 1918–1956: An Experiment in Literary Investigation, I–II | year = 1973 | publisher = [[Harper & Row]] | chapter = Chapter 3 The Interrogation | ISBN = 0060803320}}{{rp|130}} and he gave his interrogator a solid dressingdown on the problems with Bolshevism.{{rp|32}} Novelist [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]] in his book ''[[The Gulag Archipelago]]'' recounts the incident as follows:
[Berdyaev] was arrested twice; he was taken in 1922 for a midnight interrogation with [[Felix Dzerzhinsky|Dzerjinsky]]; [[Lev Kamenev|Kamenev]] was also there.... But Berdyaev did not humiliate himself, he did not beg, he firmly professed the moral and religious principles by virtue of which he did not adhere to the party in power; and not only did they judge that there was no point in putting him on trial, but he was freed. Now there is a man who had a "point of view"!Cited by Markovic, op. cit., p.33, footnote 36.
The Soviet authorities eventually expelled Berdyaev from Russia, in September 1922. He became one of a group of prominent writers, scholars and intellectuals who were [[forced exile|sent into forced exile]] on the so-called "[[philosophers' ship]]s". At first, Berdyaev and other émigrés went to [[Berlin]], where he founded an academy of philosophy and religion, but economic and political conditions in the [[Weimar Republic]] caused him and his wife to move to [[Paris]] in 1923. He transferred his academy there, and taught, lectured and wrote, working for an exchange of ideas with the [[France|French]] and European intellectual community, and participated in a number of international conferences.Vide Berdyaev, "Dream and Reality", p. 264; also by-Berdyaev 1927 article | [http://www.berdyaev.com/berdiaev/berd_lib/1927_323.html A Conference in Austria] During the [[German occupation of France during World War II]], Berdyaev continued to write books that were published after the war, some of them after his death. In the years that he spent in France, Berdyaev wrote 15 books, including most of his most important works. He died at his writing desk in his home in [[Clamart]], near Paris, in 1948. Primary source biographical works in English are Berdyaev's intellectual autobiography, published originally under the title ''Dream and Reality'', and Donald A. Lowrie's 1960 book, ''Rebellious Prophet: A Life of Nikolai Berdyaev'', written in close collaboration with Berdyaev's sister-in-law, Evgenia Rapp, and others of their close acquaintance under the auspices of the Berdiaev Société.Vide Lowrie, "Rebellious Prophet", Preface, p. ix-x ==Philosophy== David Bonner Richardson described Berdyaev's philosophy as [[Christian existentialism]] and [[personalism]].[https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-94-011-8870-8_3 Existentialism: A Personalist Philosophy of History], ''Berdyaev’s Philosophy of History. An Existentialist Theory of Social Creativity and Eschatology'', by David Bonner Richardson, pp 90-137 He emphasized the importance of [[creativity]] that requires personal freedom.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} According to Marko Markovic, "He was an ardent man, rebellious to all authority, an independent and "negative" spirit. He could assert himself only in negation and could not hear any assertion without immediately negating it, to such an extent that he would even be able to contradict himself and to attack people who shared his own prior opinions".Marko Marković, ''La Philosophie de l'inégalité et les idées politiques de Nicolas Berdiaev'' (Paris: Nouvelles Editions Latines, 1978). He also published works about Russian history and the Russian national character. In particular, he wrote about [[Russian nationalism]]:Quoted from book by [[Benedikt Sarnov]],''Our Soviet Newspeak: A Short Encyclopedia of Real Socialism.'', p. 446-447. Moscow: 2002, {{ISBN|5-85646-059-6}} (Наш советский новояз. Маленькая энциклопедия реального социализма.) {{Quotation|The Russian people did not achieve their ancient dream of Moscow, the [[Third Rome]]. [[Raskol|The ecclesiastical schism of the seventeenth century]] revealed that the muscovite tsardom is not the third Rome. The messianic idea of the Russian people assumed either an apocalyptic form or a revolutionary; and then there occurred an amazing event in the destiny of the Russian people. Instead of the Third Rome in Russia, the [[Third International]] was achieved, and many of the features of the Third Rome pass over to the Third International. The Third International is also a [[Holy Roman Empire|Holy Empire]], and it also is founded on an Orthodox faith. The Third International is not international, but a Russian national idea.}} ==Theology and relations with Russian Orthodox Church== Berdyaev was a member of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]],{{sfn|Witte|Alexander|2007|p=111-112|quote="the doctrines and practice of the Russian Orthodox Church are in the background ... of all that he wrote.... Berdyaev was [always] a son of Orthodoxy."}}{{sfn|The Living Church|1948|p=8|quote="a devout member of Russian Orthodox Church"}} and believed Orthodoxy was the religious tradition closest to [[early Christianity]].{{sfn|Berdyaev|1952|quote="Orthodoxy is that form of Christianity which suffered the least distortion in its substance as a result of human history. ... Out of all forms of Christianity it is the Orthodox Church which remained more closely tied to early Christianity."}} Berdyaev criticized Russian Orthodox Church and described his views as [[anticlerical]],, but this should be considered in context of a abusive distortion of the "we" aspect of churchly [[Sobornost]] by a pseudo "us-them" class divisive Marxist-like mentality.{{failed verification|date=April 2018}}Berdyaev |[http://www.chebucto.ns.ca/Philosophy/Sui-Generis/Berdyaev/essays/discord.htm Discord in the Church and Freedom of Conscience] He considered himself closer to Orthodoxy than either Catholicism or Protestantism. According to him, "I can not call myself a typical Orthodox of any kind; but Orthodoxy was near to me (and I hope I am nearer to Orthodoxy) than either Catholicism or Protestantism. I never severed my link with the Orthodox Church, although confessional self-satisfaction and exclusiveness are alien to me."{{sfn|Witte|Alexander|2007|p=111-112}} Berdyaev is frequently presented as one of the important Russian Orthodox thinkers of the 20th century.{{sfn|Noble|2015}}{{sfn|Valliere|2006|p=2}}{{sfn|Clarke|1950}} However, [[Patristics|neopatristic]] scholars such as [[Georges Florovsky|Florovsky]] have questioned whether his philosophy is essentially Orthodox in character, and emphasize his western influences.{{sfn|Florovsky|1950}} But Florovsky can hardly{{cn|date=April 2018}} be considered an objective unbiased critic, having been savaged in a 1937 Journal Put' article by Berdyaev,Berdyaev |[http://www.berdyaev.com/berdiaev/berd_lib/1937_424.html Ortodoksia and Humanness (Archpriest Georgii Florovsky. “The Ways of Russian Theology”, 1937, YMCA-PRESS.) Berdyaev.com along with Florovsky's own extreme ultra-Byzantine views impelling his 1955 career change. Paul Valliere has pointed out the sociological factors and global trends which have shaped the Neopatristic movement, and questions their claim that Berdyaev and [[Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)|Vladimir Solovyov]] are somehow less authentically Orthodox.{{sfn|Valliere|2006|p=3-4}} Berdyaev affirmed [[universal reconciliation|universal salvation]], as did many important Orthodox theologians of the 20th century.{{sfn|Cunningham|Theokritoff|2008|p=118}} Along with [[Sergei Bulgakov]], he was instrumental in bringing renewed attention to the Orthodox doctrine of [[apokatastasis]], which had largely been neglected since it was expounded by [[Maximus the Confessor]] in the seventh century,{{sfn|Blowers|2008|p=37}} although he rejected [[Origen]]'s articulation of this doctrine.{{sfn|Deak|1977|p=20-60}}{{sfn|Kirwan|Hidden|2016|p=41-42}} The aftermath of the Russian Revolution and Civil War, along with Soviet interference, caused the Russian Orthodox emigre diaspora to splinter into three Russian Church jurisdictions: the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]] (in schism from Moscow Patriarchate until 2007); the parishes under Metropolitan [[Eulogius (Georgiyevsky)]] that went under the Constantinople [[Ecumenical Patriarchate]]; and parishes that remained under the [[Moscow Patriarchate]]. Berdyaev was among those that chose to remain under the omophor of the [[Moscow Patriarchate]]. He is mentioned by name on the Kosun/Chersonese Diocesan history{{cite web|url=https://www.cerkov-ru.eu/istoriya-eparhii/|title=ИСТОРИЯ ЕПАРХИИ|website=Cerkov-ru.eu|accessdate=17 May 2018}} as among those noted figures who supported the Moscow Patriarchate West-European Eparchy (in France now Korsun eparchy). Currently, the house in Clamart in which Berdyaev lived, now comprises a small "Berdiaev-museum" and attached Chapel in name of the Holy Spirit,{{cite web|url=https://www.cerkov-ru.eu/item/chasovnya-v-chest-svyatogo-duha-v-klamare|title=Часовня в честь Святого Духа в Кламаре|website=Cerkov-ru.eu|accessdate=17 May 2018}} under the omophor of the Moscow Patriarchate. On 24 March 2018, the 70th anniversary of Berdyaev's death, the priest of the Chapel served panikhida-memorial prayer at the Diocesan cathedral for eternal memory of Berdyaev,{{cite web|url=https://www.egliserusse.eu/Il-y-a-70-ans-Nicolas-Berdiaev-1874-1948--celebre-philosophe-russe-etait-rappele-a-Dieu_a1661.html|title=Il y a 70 ans, Nicolas Berdiaev (1874-1948), célèbre philosophe russe, était rappelé à Dieu|first=Prêtre Georges|last=SHESHKO|website=Egliserusse.eu|accessdate=17 May 2018}} and later that day the Diocesan bishop Nestor(Sirotenko) presided over prayer at the grave of Berdyaev.{{cite web|url=https://www.cerkov-ru.eu/novosti/ispolnilos-70-let-so-dnya-konchiny-izvestnogo-russkogo-filosofa-nikolaya-berdyaeva/|title=Исполнилось 70 лет со дня кончины известного русского философа Николая Бердяева|website=Cerkov-ru.eu|accessdate=17 May 2018}} ==Works== The first date is of the Russian edition, the second date is of the first English edition * ''Subjectivism and Individualism in Societal Philosophy'' (1901) * ''The New Religious Consciousness and Society'' (1907) ({{lang-ru|Новое религиозное сознание и общественность|Novoe religioznoe coznanie i obschestvennost}}, includes chapter VI "The Metaphysics of Sex and Love")The book is not available in English. {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} '''''Nolle prosequi''''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|n|ɒ|l|i|_|ˈ|p|r|ɒ|s|ə|k|w|aɪ}};<ref name="oed">{{OED|Nolle prosequi}}</ref> {{IPA-la|ˈnolːe ˈproːsekwiː|classical}}) is a legal [[term of art]] and a [[List of Latin legal phrases|Latin legal phrase]] meaning "be unwilling to pursue",<ref name="refdotcom">"[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Nolle+prosequi Nolle prosequi]". reference.com. Accessed 2012-03-02.</ref><ref name="perseus.tufts.edu">"[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0060%3Aentry%3Dprosequor Nolle prosequi]". Lewis & Short. Accessed 2017-02-17.</ref> a phrase amounting to "do not prosecute". It is a phrase used in many [[common law]] [[criminal jurisdiction|criminal]] prosecution contexts to describe a [[prosecutor]]'s decision to voluntarily discontinue [[criminal law|criminal]] charges either before [[trial (law)|trial]] or before a [[verdict]] is rendered.<ref>A ''nolle prosequi'' can be entered at any time after the indictment or information has been signed and before verdict:''R v Dunn [http://www.worldlii.org/int/cases/EngR/1843/60.pdf <nowiki>[1843]</nowiki> {{abbr|EngR|English Reports}} 60]; R v Colling (1847) 2 [[Cox's Criminal Cases|Cox CC]] [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tGk0AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA184#v=onepage&q&f=false 184]; R v Sneesby (1951) [[State Reports Queensland|St R Qd]] 26; {{cite AustLII|SASC|1670|1989|litigants=R v Economou |paralleicte=(1989) 51 [[South Australian State Reports|SASR]] 421}}; {{cite AustLII|TASRp|16|1979|litigants=R v Heald |parallecite=[1979] [[Tasmanian Reports|Tas R]] 185}} source: {{cite AustLII|SASC|5679|1996|litigants=R v Michael Charles Baenisch |date=28 June 1996 |pinpoint=para. 12}}.</ref> It contrasts with an [[involuntary dismissal]].
== Application in law == ''Nolle prosequi'' as a declaration is most often used in criminal cases, but in jurisdictions making use of ''nolle prosequi'' in civil lawsuits, it is used by a plaintiff that voluntarily drops its claims. In civil cases, a motion for [[voluntary dismissal]] may be made by a plaintiff instead of a declaration of ''nolle prosequi'', depending upon the custom and rules of a given jurisdiction.
=== Decision-maker === ''Nolle prosequi'' as a declaration can be made by a prosecutor in a criminal case either before or during trial, resulting in the prosecutor declining to further pursue the case against the defendant. Courts seldom challenge applications for ''nolle prosequi''. In the [[United States]], judges will usually sign a dismissal order prepared by the prosecution or make a docket entry indicating the disposition of the case to be ''nolle prosse'' after a declaration or motion by the prosecution.
In criminal cases in the United States it has been held improper for a court to enter an order of ''nolle prosequi'' on its own, without a motion by the prosecutor,<ref name="cox">[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=4202544690014107094&hl=en United States v. Cox], 342 F.2d 167 (5th Cir.) (en banc), cert denied, 381 U.S. 935 (1965). Involved a federal grand jury indictment against civil rights workers and the refusal by a US attorney to sign the indictment. The Fifth Circuit held that the US attorney's signing or withholding of his signature was within prosecutorial discretion and could not be coerced by the courts. See also the dicta in US v. Nixon, 418 U.S. 683 at 693, 1974, "[The] Executive Branch has exclusive authority and absolute discretion to decide whether to prosecute a case." (citing Cox).</ref> but as to sentencing discrepancies involved in a sentence recommendation, a trial judge is authorized to reject an underlying guilty plea based upon concerns of fairness and justice or because it is presented after the plea cutoff date.<ref name="grove">[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=4529448885415177681&hl=en People v. Grove], 566 N.W.2d 547 at 556, Mich. Sup. Ct. 1997, and cited by Casenote: Criminal Law – Plea Bargaining, 75 U. Det. Mercy L. Rev. 741, Summer, 1998.</ref> The notes to Rule 48 of the US [[Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure]] (FRCRP) draw attention to the effect of the rule as contrasting with common law. Rule 48 now mandates for prosecutors to seek leave of the court before they dismiss a case via filing a ''nolle prosequi''.<ref name="frcpNote">[https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/frcrmp/rule_48 FRCRP 48 notes], cornell.edu. Retrieved 2011-11-8.</ref>
=== Reason === The declaration may be made because the charges cannot be proved because the evidence is too weak to carry the burden of proof, the evidence is fatally flawed in light of the claims that are brought,<ref name="snead">Snead v. Jones, 169 Ala. 143, 53 So. 188; MacLaughlin v. Lehigh Valley R. Co., 93 N. J. L. 263, 108 Atl. 309; Dickerson v. Atlantic Refining Co., 201 N. C. 90, 159 S.E. 446; Hobbs v. Illinois Cent. R. Co., 182 Iowa 316, 165 N.W. 912.</ref> the prosecutor becomes doubtful that the accused is guilty, the defendant's innocence is proved, or the defendant has died. It has also been used when a federal criminal charge is brought up against a defendant when the prosecutor on a state charge for the same offense no longer wishes to pursue the case. Usually, that happens when the state prosecutor is content with the sentence on the federal charge and has no need to go any further with the original case.
=== Timing === In criminal cases, ''nolle prosequi'' declarations are made generally after an indictment as long as adjudication on the merits has not occurred or, in some jurisdictions, as long as a trial has not commenced. In civil cases, ''nolle prosequi'' declarations are made either before the trial begins or before a judgment on the merits is rendered, depending on the rules of the jurisdiction.
=== Legal effect === The entry of a ''nolle prosequi'' is not an acquittal. Since the principle of [[double jeopardy]] therefore does not apply, the defendant may later be indicted on the same charge again.<ref name="klopfer">[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=4221560055012353994&hl=en Klopfer v. North Carolina], 386 US 213 at 214, 87 S. Ct. 988, 18 L. Ed. 2d 1, Sup. Ct., 1967.</ref><ref name="swick">[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=17187521144565403858&hl=en Swick v. Liautaud], 662 NE 2d 1238, 169 Ill. 2d 504, Ill Sup. Ct., 1996.</ref><ref>Klopfer at 215 et seq..</ref><ref name="wynne">[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=1665611583418567020&hl=en Wynne v. Rosen], 464 NE 2d 1348, Mass Sup. J. Ct., 1984.</ref>
=== Application in civil cases === In civil cases, a ''nolle prosequi'' or voluntary dismissal may be entered as to one of several counts or claims, or as to one of several defendants, or both. In any jurisdiction, whether a motion for voluntary dismissal or a declaration of ''nolle prosequi'' is used, federal and state rules of [[civil procedure]] generally govern when, how, and why claims may be voluntarily dismissed and apply different rules to different types of claims and to whether a court may give leave to dismiss a matter with or without [[prejudice (legal procedure)|prejudice]].<ref name="frcp">See [[Federal Rules of Civil Procedure|FRCP]] Rule 41, for example.</ref>
== Similarity to a declination of prosecution == ''Nolle prosequi'' is similar to a declination of prosecution, which is an agreement not to prosecute made before any charges are brought or suit has been filed. A declination of prosecution may be made by an attorney or may be made as an agreement between the aggrieved party and the claimant.
In contrast, ''nolle prosequi'' is usually made after a decision to prosecute has already been made. A declination of prosecution may be made for many reasons, such as weak evidence or a conflict of interest.<ref name="greenblum">Greenblum, [http://www.corporatecrimereporter.com/documents/greenblum.pdf What Happens to a Prosecution Deferred-Judicial Oversight of Corporate Deferred Prosecution Agreements] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119054112/http://www.corporatecrimereporter.com/documents/greenblum.pdf |date=19 January 2012 }}, 105 Colum. L. Rev. 1863 at 1868, 2005.</ref>
== Notable cases == {{unordered list | The 1868 trial of [[Jefferson Davis]] after a declaration of general amnesty by President [[Andrew Johnson]]. | The 1902 [[Peasenhall Murder]] in Suffolk in England. | In 1924, Connecticut prosecutor [[Homer Stille Cummings]] dismissed charges against [[Harold Israel]], a vagrant accused of murdering a popular priest in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]]. Cummings destroyed the evidence his own office had compiled against Israel in a 90-minute courtroom presentation. The case became the basis of the 1947 film ''[[Boomerang (1947 film)|Boomerang!]]''<ref name='War'>Mckenna, Marian C., [https://books.google.com/books?id=oPBjQegx8ZIC&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=harold+israel+cummings#v=onepage&q=harold%20israel%20cummings&f=false Franklin Roosevelt and the great constitutional war], Fordham University Press, 2002, pp. 8–9. {{ISBN|0-8232-2154-7}}</ref> | In 1925, prosecutors elected to dismiss [[murder]] charges against the remaining ten defendants in the famous case of ''People vs. [[Ossian Sweet]]''. It involved a [[black people|black]] family that had defended its home against a [[white people|white]] mob. They were defended by attorney [[Clarence Darrow]], who was retained by the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]]. The trial was presided over by [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]] [[Recorder's Court]] [[Judge]] [[Frank Murphy]], who went on to become an [[Associate Justice]] of the [[Supreme Court of the United States]]. After an initial [[mistrial (law)|mistrial]], Henry Sweet (Ossian's brother, who admitted he fired the shot) was [[acquittal|acquitted]] by a [[jury]] on grounds of [[Right of self-defense|self defense]]; the dismissals of the charges against the ten remaining defendants followed.<ref>[[Kevin Boyle (historian)|Boyle, Kevin]], [[Arc of Justice: A Saga of Race, Civil Rights and Murder in the Jazz Age]], Henry Holt & Company, New York: 2004. ([[National Book Award]] Winner). {{ISBN|0-8050-7933-5}}; {{ISBN|978-0-8050-7933-3}}.</ref> <!--Note: Arc of Justice is wikilinked because all [[List of winners of the National Book Award]] are.--> | In 1957, [[John Bodkin Adams]], who worked in [[Eastbourne]], [[England]], was tried for the murders of an elderly widow, [[Edith Alice Morrell]] and [[indicted]] for the murder of another widow [[Gertrude Hullett]]. When he was found not guilty of killing the former, Attorney-General Sir [[Reginald Manningham-Buller]] controversially entered a ''nolle prosequi'' regarding the latter charge. The trial judge, Mr Justice [[Patrick Devlin, Baron Devlin|Patrick Devlin]], in his post-trial book commented:<ref name="devlin">Devlin, Patrick, Easing the Passing: the trial of Dr John Bodkin Adams, London : The Bodley Head, 1985, pp. 181. {{ISBN|0-370-30627-9}}</ref> {{quotation |The use of ''nolle prosequi'' to conceal the deficiencies of the prosecution was an abuse of process, which left an innocent man under the suspicion that there might have been something in the talk of mass murder after all.}} The author Patricia Cullen described Manningham-Buller's use of ''nolle prosequi'' as a '[[sword of Damocles]]' hanging over Adams,<ref name="cul">Cullen, Pamela V., A Stranger in Blood: The Case Files on Dr John Bodkin Adams, London : Elliott & Thompson, 2006. {{ISBN|1-904027-19-9}}</ref> but this is inconsistent with Devlin's account. | In 1982, a prosecution concerning the play ''[[The Romans In Britain]]'' by [[Howard Brenton]] collapsed after it was demonstrated that what a witness had thought was an erect penis shown on stage during a [[male rape]] scene, was in fact an actor's thumb. The case had been brought at the urging of the morality campaigner [[Mary Whitehouse]], who had not seen the play; it was ended with a ''nolle prosequi''. | In 2004, [[rape]] charges against [[basketball]] player [[Kobe Bryant]] were dropped after the [[complainant]] refused to testify. | In 2011, as a result of [[Death of Osama Bin Laden|his death]], charges against [[Osama bin Laden]] were dropped with the filing of a ''nolle prosequi'' in a Manhattan federal court by the [[U.S. Department of Justice]].<ref name="nydaily">{{cite news | title=Federal judge drops embassy blast charges against Osama bin Laden | publisher=[[NY Daily News]] | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2011/06/17/2011-06-17_federal_judge_drops_embassy_blast_charges_against_osama_bin_laden_.html?r=news/ny_crime | date=2011-06-17 | accessdate=2011-06-19 | last=Shifrel | first=Scott}}</ref>}}

{{for|the a weapon in Hindu mythology, considered most destructive|Pashupatastra}} {{Saivism}} '''Pashupata Shaivism''' ('''{{IAST|Pāśupata}}''', {{lang-sa|पाशुपत}}) is the oldest of the major [[Shaivism|Shaivite]] Hindu schools.<ref>For the Pāśupatas as the oldest named Śaiva group, see: Flood (2003), p. 206.</ref> There is a debate about pioneership of this school and Goan school of Nakulish darshan believes that Nakulish was pioneer and Lakulish and Patanjalinath were his disciples while Gujrat school believes that Nakulish and Lakulish are one. Sarwdarshansangrah written by Madhavachary mentiones it as "Nakulish Darshan" not as "Lakulish Darshan" Both sub schools are still active in their own areas. The philosophy of the Pashupata sect was systematized by {{IAST|Lakulīśa}} also called Nakulīśa<ref>Cowell and Gough, p. 108.</ref>) in the 2nd century A.D. The main texts of the school are ''{{IAST|Pāśupatasūtra}}'' with Kauṇḍinya's ''{{IAST|Pañcārthabhāṣya}}'', and ''{{IAST|Gaṇakārikā}}'' with Bhāsarvajña's ''{{IAST| Ratnaṭīkā}}''. Both texts were discovered only in the twentieth century. Prior to that, the major source of information on this sect was a chapter devoted to it in {{IAST|Vidyāraṇya}}'s ''{{IAST|Sarvadarśanasaṅgraha}}''.
==Date== The date of foundation of the school is uncertain. However, the Pashupatas may have existed from the 1st century CE.<ref>For dating as first century AD, with uncertainty, see: Michaels (2004), p. 62.</ref> Gavin Flood dates them to around the 2nd century CE.<ref>For dating from probably second century AD, see: Flood (2003), p. 206.</ref> They are also referred to in the epic [[Mahabharata]] which is thought to have reached a final form by 4th century CE.<ref>[[Mahabharata#cite note-vanB73-9|Buitenen (1973) pp. xxiv–xxv]]</ref> The Pashupata movement was influential in [[South India]] in the period between the 7th and 14th century, but it no longer exists.<ref name=gale/>
==Overview== {{Hindu philosophy}} Pashupata Shaivism was a devotional ([[bhakti]]) and ascetic movement.<ref name=gale>Lorenzen, David N. ''Śaivism''. An Overview, [in]: Gale's Encyclopedia of Religion, vol. 12, 2005, {{ISBN|0-02-865981-3}}</ref><ref>For Pāśupata as an ascetic movement see: Michaels (2004), p. 62.</ref> Pashu in [[Pashupati]] refers to the effect (or created world), the word designates that which is dependent on something ulterior. Whereas, Pati means the cause (or principium), the word designates the Lord, who is the cause of the universe, the pati, or the ruler.<ref name="cowell1">Cowell and Gough, p. 104-105.</ref> To free themselves from worldly fetters Pashupatas are instructed to do a '''pashupata vrata'''. Atharvasiras Upanishsad describes the pashupata vrata as that which consists of besmearing one's own body with ashes and at the same time muttering [[mantra]] — "Agni is ashes, Vayu is ashes, Sky is ashes, all this is ashes, the mind, these eyes are ashes."<ref>Indian History, V. K. Agnihottri, 2003. {{ISBN|81-7764-393-2}}.</ref>
Haradattacharya, in [[Gaṇakārikā]], explains that a spiritual teacher is one who knows the eight [[pentads]] and the three functions. The eight pentads of Acquisition (result of expedience), Impurity (evil in soul), Expedient (means of purification), Locality (aids to increase knowledge), Perseverance (endurance in pentads), Purification (putting away impurities), Initiation and Powers are<ref name="cowell1"/> — {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: small; text-align: center; width: auto;" |- !Acquisition |knowledge |penance |permanence of the body |constancy |purity |- !Impurity |false conception |demerit |attachment |interestedness |falling |- !Expedient |use of habitation |pious muttering |meditation |constant recollection of [[Rudra]] |apprehension |- !Locality |spiritual teachers |a cavern |a special place |the burning ground |Rudra |- !Perseverance |the differenced |the undifferenced |muttering |acceptance |devotion |- !Purification |loss of ignorance |loss of demerit |loss of attachment |loss of interestedness |loss of falling |- !Initiations |the material |proper time |the rite |the image |the spiritual guide |- !Powers |devotion to the spiritual guide |clearness of intellect |conquest of pleasure and pain |[[Merit (Buddhism)|merit]] |carefulness |} The three functions correspond to the means of earning daily food — mendicancy, living upon alms, and living upon what chance supplies.<ref name="cowell1"/>
==Philosophy== Pashupatas disapprove of the [[Vaishnava]] theology, known for its doctrine servitude of souls to the Supreme Being, on the grounds that dependence upon anything cannot be the means of cessation of pain and other desired ends. They recognize that those depending upon another and longing for independence will not be emancipated because they still depend upon something other than themselves. According to Pashupatas, spirits possess the attributes of the Supreme Deity when they become liberated from the 'germ of every pain'.<ref>Cowell and Gough, p. 103</ref> In this system the cessation of pain is of two kinds, impersonal and personal. Impersonal consists of the absolute cessation of all pains, whereas the personal consists of development of visual and active powers like swiftness of thought, assuming forms at will etc. The Lord is held to be the possessor of infinite, visual, and active powers.<ref>Cowell and Gough, p. 106</ref>
Pañchārtha bhāshyadipikā divides the created world into the insentient and the sentient. The insentient is unconscious and thus dependent on the conscious. The insentient is further divided into effects and causes. The effects are of ten kinds, the earth, [[Classical element|four elements]] and their qualities, colour etc. . The causes are of thirteen kinds, the five organs of cognition, the five organs of action, the three internal organs, intellect, the ego principle and the cognising principle. These insentient causes are held responsible for the illusive identification of [[Ātman (Hinduism)|Self]] with non-Self. The sentient spirit, which is subject to [[Transmigration of the soul|transmigration]] is of two kinds, the appetent and nonappetent. The appetent is the spirit associated with an organism and sense organs, whereas the non-appetent is the spirit without them.<ref name="Cowell7">Cowell and Gough, p. 107</ref>
Union in the Pashupata system is a conjunction of the soul with God through the intellect. It is achieved in two ways, action and cessation of action. Union through action consists of pious muttering, meditation etc. and union through cessation of action occurs through consciousness.<ref name="Cowell7"/>
==Rituals== Rituals and [[spiritual practices]] were done to acquire [[Merit (Buddhism)|merit]] or puṇya. They were divided into primary and secondary rituals, where primary rituals were the direct means of acquiring merit. Primary rituals included acts of piety and various postures. The acts of piety were bathing thrice a day, lying upon sand and worship with oblations of laughter, song, dance, sacred muttering etc. Postures involved absurd actions such as, snoring or showing signs of being asleep while awake, limping, wooing or gestures of an inamorato on seeing a young and pretty woman, talking nonsensically etc. Secondary rituals involved bearing marks of purity after bathing.<ref>Cowell and Gough, p. 108-109.</ref>
==Beliefs and practices== Lakulisa is credited with authorship of the ''Pancharthavidya'', in which devotees are instructed to "bathe thrice a day" and "lie on the dust or ashes". This "Pasupata Vow" is also described in the [[Atharvasiras Upanishad]].<ref name="Indian History 2003">Indian History, A.K. Agnihotri, 2003.</ref>
The Pasupatas worshiped Lord Shiva as God Almighty. They would bathe their body three times a day in sand, lie in ashes, sing bhajans of Shiva.<ref name="ReferenceA">Bhushan, P. 50, ''Religious Beliefs and Practices of North India During the Early Mediaeval Period''</ref>
Laughing was also an important Pasupata practice, as was physically shaking and meditation.<ref name="ReferenceB">[[Klaus Klostermaier|Klostermaier]], P. 234, ''A Survey of Hinduism''</ref>
They call the union ([[Moksha]]) with Shiva, "Rudrasajujya."<ref name="ReferenceC">Muller-Ortega, P. 32, The Triadic Heart of Śiva: Kaula Tantricism of Abhinavagupta in the Non-Dual)</ref>
==Five major principles== According to Govind Chandra Pande,<ref>P. 155 Foundations of Indian Culture by Govind Chandra Pande</ref> there are given major principles which the Pasupata members adhere to: #creature ("Karya") #creator ("Karana") #esoteric worship ("Yoga") #ritual ("Vishi") #salvation ("dukhanta")
==Sects== The Pasupatas are known to have had sects within the Pasupata sect. For example, the Lakulins are said to be a sub-sect. The Tripurantaka sect are also said to be the same. Their scripture is the Cintra prashasti.<ref name="Majumdar, P. 292">Majumdar, P. 292</ref> They were found in Gujarat up to the Chalukya era.<ref name="Majumdar, P. 292"/> The Lalikesa Sasana were another sect.<ref>Dajee, P. 221 Writings and Speeches of Dr. Bhau Daji</ref>
It is said that "Lakulisa" became the name of the Pasupata sects at least after the 11th century CE.<ref>Briggs, P. 220, Gorakhnatha and the Kanphata Yogis</ref> The Lakulin sect is also known by the names "Lakulasamaya", "Lakula", "Lanjana", "Laguda", "Langala", "Nakula", "Vakula."<ref> Dyczkowski, P, 21, The Canon of the Saivagama and the Kubjika Tantras of the Western Kaul Tradition</ref>
==Pasupatism historically practiced== Temples with the carvings of Lakulisa are found in western regions of India as that is where it originated although it is also found in the east as far as Orissa, south to Tamil Nadu and north to Kashmir.
===Western India=== The practice of course began in western India and so spread amongst areas of the west. many images of Lakula have been found in areas such as Rajasthan.<ref>Farquhar, P. 146, ''An Outline of the Religious Literature of India''</ref> Fergusson assigned temples from Rajasthan down to Andhra as belonging to the Pasupatas.<ref>Farquhar, P. 146, ''An Outline of the Religious Literature of India''</ref> The region around Mt. Abu was the principal place of Pasuapta activities.<ref name="Majumdar, P. 294">Majumdar, P. 294</ref> MadhyaPradesh too has a treasure of images of Lakula found from places like Mandsaur, Ujjain, etc.
Along with other forms of Shiva, there is a painting of Lakulisa in an Ellora cave of Maharashtra.<ref name="Rānaḍe, P. 36 Ellora paintings">Rānaḍe, P. 36 ''Ellora paintings''</ref>
===Northern India=== "The form of Saivism in Kashmir during the early period was of the Pasupata sect. According to a tradition recorded in the Mahabharata, the doctrine of Pasupata was first preached by Siva Srikantha. Siva Srikantha was regarded in the Valley to as the promulgator or Sivagama or Agamanta Saivism which included the system of the Pasupata."<ref>Bamzai, P. 202, ''Culture and Political History of Kashmir''</ref>
===Southern India=== In Tamil Nadu, it is known to have existed in the modern-day district of Tiruvottiyur, and in Kashmir in Payar, where there are Lakulisa figures found.<ref>Chakravarti, P. 63, ''The Concept of Rudra-Siva Through the Ages''</ref> In Tamil Nadu, it also existed in Tanjore and Nagapattnam.<ref>Shah, P. xi, Studies in Jaina Art and Iconography and Allied Subjects in Honour of Dr. U</ref>
According to the findings of the Archaeological Survey of India, Bijjaladeva of the Chalukyan Empire of Southern India and parts of Northern India, donated a gift in the service to God. The gift was made after washing the feet of Divyasakti-Panditadeva, a Lakulin.
===Nepal=== As the ''Hinduism Today'' article reports: :"A seventh-century Chinese traveler, Hiuen Tsiang, wrote that 10,000 Pashupatas then occupied Varanasi. The Pashupata tradition spread to Nepal in the eighth century, where the now famous Pashupatinath Temple became a prime pilgrimage center and remains so to this day. At its medieval zenith, Pashupatism blanketed Western, Northwestern and Southeastern India, where it received royal patronage. In the fifteenth century, it retreated to its strongholds of Gujarat, Nepal and the Himalayan hills" (March 1994, "Pashupata Saivism") It is believed by some scholars that they may have been absorbed into other sects such as the Kanpatha Yoga.<ref>Wilson, P. 18''Religious Sects of the Hindus''</ref>
To King Ishttanga's rule (915-930 CE) is attributed the building of a Pasupata temple.<ref>(Hāṇḍā & Handa, P. 34 ''History of Uttaranchal''</ref>
There is a Nakuleshvara Temple complex in Kalighata, West Bengal.<ref>''University of Calcutta'', P. 23 By Calcutta Review</ref>
===Indonesia=== It has been theorized by a few scholars such as Dale Hoiberg and Indu Ramchandani state that the sect existed in Cambodia and Java, Indonesia.<ref>P. 160 ''Students' Britannica India'' By Dale Hoiberg and Indu Ramchandani</ref>
==Reference in scriptures== The Pasupata beliefs are summarized in the ''Pasaputa Sutra''. This text was rediscovered in 1930 and is attributed to Lakulisa himself.<ref>Subramuniyaswami, P. 809, Dancing With Siva: Hinduism's Contemporary Catechism</ref> Bhanmdarkar attributes the ''Atharva-Siras''to the Pasupatas.<ref>Pillai, P. 321, Indian Sociology Through Ghurye</ref> Also, in the text, their vow is recorded.<ref>Briggs, P. 220, Gorakhnatha and the Kanphata Yogis</ref>
The [[Mahabharata]] claimed that he was a son of Lord [[Brahma]] and taught people the Pasupata system.<ref>Klostermaier, Klaus, P. 168, Mythologies and Philosophies of Salvation in the Theistic Traditions of India</ref> In the Mahabharata, Srikantha (or Lakulisa) claims that the Pasupata system is a son of Lord Brahma when a form of Shiva emerged from Lord Brahma's eyebrow (MBh (B), 12, 349-67) <ref>Stietencron, P. 108, Hindu Myth, Hindu History, Religion, Art, and Politics</ref>
The ''Sarva-Darsana-Samgraha'' of the Advaitin saint Madhavacarya wrote in the text, the philosophical system of Lakulin. Kaundinya's or Rashikara's ''Pancharta Bhasya'' discusses this sect.<ref>Pande, P. 155, Foundations of Indian Culture</ref> The ''Gana-karika'' of Bhasarvajna too discusses this school in detail.<ref>Pande, P. 155, Foundations of Indian Culture</ref> The Pasupata system is mentioned in the ''Vayuviha Samhita''.<ref>Dasgupta, P. 10 A History of Indian Philosophy</ref>
Some people including compilers of the [[Vayu Purana|Vayu]] and [[Linga Purana|Linga]] puranas to be a corresponding system of the Pancharatna.<ref>Majumdar, P. 293 Chaulukyas of Gujarat</ref>

'''Petrus Martinez de Osma''' ({{lang-es|Pedro Martínez de Osma}}) (died 1480) was a Spanish theologian and philosopher, known for his views on [[indulgence]]s, which he retracted at the end of his life. ==Life== He graduated M.A. at the [[University of Salamanca]] in 1457. He was professor of theology there from 1463.{{cite book|author=Friedrich Stegmüller|title=Repertorium Biblicum Medii Aevi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sDgRm1-1MW0C&pg=PA340|accessdate=3 August 2012|year=1950|publisher=Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas, Instituto Francisco Suárez|isbn=978-84-00-06980-3|page=340|language=la}} A follower of [[Alonso Tostado|Alonso el Madrigal (el Tostado)]], from 1476 he defended theses on indulgences and [[Confession (religion)|confession]] resembling those of [[John Wyclif]] and [[Jan Hus]], and anticipating issues from the [[Protestant Reformation]]. Among his pupils was [[Antonio de Nebrija]].{{cite book|author=Collectif|title=Atalaya. Revue française d'études médiévales hispaniques, n°2/automne 1991: Écrits et lectures au Moyen Âge. Espagne, France, Italie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OdVJq6tuHA8C&pg=PA172|accessdate=3 August 2012|date=1 January 1993|publisher=Presses Sorbonne Nouvelle|isbn=978-2-87854-028-4|page=172|language=fr}} The views of Martinez encountered opposition, particularly from [[Juan López de Salamanca]].{{cite book|author=Gerard Albert Wiegers|title=Islamic Literature in Spanish and Aljamiado: Yça of Segovia (fl. 1450), His Antecendents and Successors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z2A55_kw3F4C&pg=PA219|accessdate=3 August 2012|year=1994|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-09936-4|page=219}} In 1478, as the [[Spanish Inquisition]] was being instituted, the Inquisition of [[Saragossa]] passed judgement, Martinez was summoned in 1479 before [[Alfonso Carillo de Acuña]], [[archbishop of Toledo]], and other theologians. His ideas were declared heretical, a judgement backed by a [[papal bull]] of [[Pope Sixtus IV]].{{cite book|author=Ana (ed.) Chaguaceda Toledano|title=Miguel de Unamuno. Estudios sobre su obra. II|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VjEFgKwbMwkC&pg=PA49|accessdate=3 August 2012|year=2005|publisher=Universidad de Salamanca|isbn=978-84-7800-592-5|pages=49–|language=es}}{{cite book|author=Luis Enrique(et.al)(coord.) Rodríguez-San Pedro Bezares|title=Historia de la Universidad de Salamanca. Volumen III:Saberes y confluencias|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O02pQqwSNdoC&pg=PA192|accessdate=3 August 2012|year=2006|publisher=Universidad de Salamanca|isbn=978-84-7800-118-7|page=192|language=es}} After his views were condemned, the book ''De confessione'', written by Martinez on the occasion of the [[plenary indulgence]] of 1475, was burned; and he submitted.{{cite book|author=Joseph F. O'Callaghan|title=A History of Medieval Spain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yA3p6v3UxyIC&pg=PA634|accessdate=3 August 2012|year=1975|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-9264-8|page=634}}{{cite book|author=Horacio Santiago-Otero|title=Fé y cultura en la Edad Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rUtV12-vCmwC&pg=PA279|accessdate=3 August 2012|year=1988|publisher=CSIC-Dpto. de Publicaciones|isbn=978-84-00-06852-3|page=279|language=fr}} Martinez died at [[Alba de Tormes]] in April 1480. ==Works== In Martinez [[Thomism]] was combined with [[Renaissance humanism]]; he opposed the philosophical style of [[nominalism]]. He wrote commentaries on ethics and metaphysics.{{cite book|author=John Marenbon|title=The Oxford Handbook of Medieval Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2TbPp5I6nL8C&pg=PA233|accessdate=3 August 2012|date=14 June 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-537948-8|page=233}} Martinez, through also his follower [[Diego de Deza]], reformed the Salamanca syllabus to include Aristotelian physics and metaphysics, and influenced teaching at [[Seville]].{{cite book|author=Luis M. Girón-Negrón|title=Alfonso de la Torre's Visión Deleytable: Philosophical Rationalism and the Religious Imagination in 15th Century Spain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I57B2eUj9XgC&pg=PA4|accessdate=3 August 2012|year=2001|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-11957-4|page=7}} * Ricardo García Villoslada - Bernardino Llorca, ''Historia de la Iglesia Católica'', vol. III: Edad Nueva, BAC, Madrid 2005, {{ISBN|84-7914-394-0}} * Santiago-Otero, Horacio y Reinhardt, Klaus, ''Pedro Martínez de Osma y el método teológico: edición de varios escritos inéditos'', CSIC, Madrid-Soria 1987 * Santiago Galán, ''El tratado musical de Pedro Martínez de Osma, un testimonio recuperado del siglo XV'', Cuadernos de música iberoamericana, 30, 2017, {{ISSN|1136-5536}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://thesaurus.cerl.org/record/cnp00403217 CERL page] {{DEFAULTSORT:Martinez de Osma, Petrus}} [[Category:1480 deaths]] [[Category:Spanish Christian theologians]] [[Category:Spanish philosophers]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:University of Salamanca alumni]] [[Category:University of Salamanca faculty]] [[Category:Medieval Spanish theologians]]
